text.plain_text:
Day 4, Thursday, April 24th: Florence, Italy! The highlight of the whole trip! Disembark in the coastal town of Livorno, Italy in a bit of a rush. Today is Italian Liberation Day (Festa della Liberazione) celebrating the end of WWII and the end of Nazi occupation (not to mention the Italian's own dangerous indulgence of fascism). To mark the occasion, the city belatedly announced the removal of a recently discovered WWII bomb from the harbor, that would close it down at 9:00 am. Our tour departures all got bumped up an hour as a result.

We hopped on the bus for a 2 hour countryside drive to Florence for a half day with our singing guide Samuelé Socci (no really, he's got an album and everything, http://samtheguide.com) and driver Roberto. The countryside is beautiful, and the guide informative. Stopped at McDonald's on the way for snacks and (old lady bladder) relief! Weird!

Florence is amazing, we are immediately smitten. It appears that the whole city is a museum (with a horde of people living in it). Will plan to go back and do it justice for 5 days minimum. 

The first destination on our guided tour is the Academia Di Belle Arti, featuring an array of paintings and sculpture, principally, the original David, by Michelangelo Buonaparte (no photography unfortunately, adhering to their persistent Italian fascist instincts). Words cannot express the awe we felt in the presence of these iconic works—unforgettable.

Next we toured the Piazza del Duomo featuring the Baptistry doors by Ghiberti, and the Basilica di Santa Maria del Fiore (flower), commonly referred to simply as the Duomo because of Filippo Brunelleschi's magnificent dome, completed in 1436. His works (including perfecting the methods of linear perspectives) are said to have been largely responsible for launching the renaissance. The number of artists, architects, engineers and thinkers whom he inspired changed the course of western civilization by signifying that man could be the master of his environment without god's intercession. Alas we had no time to go in the duomo (I have to go back someday and climb the cupola—a lifetime goal).

Many of the street signs are mini art projects, altered with paint and vinyl tape to make whimsical changes. 

Too soon, we hustle along to the Piazza Della Signoria (effectively, the seat of government back in the day) where the Medici established their hold on Florence, first as enlightened and benevolent leaders, and later as ruthless despots (always and everywhere, absolute power corrupts absolutely). The square is surrounded by sculpture and is dominated by the tower and government building (now a museum we didn't have time to see) where a replica of the David stands in its original location. Much of the later (gruesomely inspired) sculpture was commissioned by the city state's ruthless and bloodthirsty despots as a not–so–subtle warning to those who might wish to cross them.

From there we rushed through the crushing throngs to an outdoor covered market called Fontana del Porcellino (pig) and on to the Porte Vecchio bridge shops. The market features a bronze boar (seen here with our guide Sam) that patrons touch for luck (reminiscent of the bronze pig at Pike Place Market in Seattle). No time allotted for shopping (a sure sign that your guide receives no commission from these shopkeeps 😳).

The Ponte Vecchio way, and the bridge itself, was lined with hi–end boutiques and gold and jewelry merchants — so overpriced that the ship's advisors and our guides warned us all to keep our wallets in our pockets for better deals elsewhere (and his commissions). Apparently most tourists got the same advice, the street was jammed with people posing and taking pictures of empty shops. We can confirm the prices were outrageous. Christoff, Gavin and I found this part of the tour interesting but overrated. Architecturally, not that great either, although it does illustrate how perceived value drove Italians to great lengths to build in improbable places and manners (note the accreted, crammed and clinging additions cantilevered and propped beyond the edge of the bridge).

After a too quick dash through additional fascinating streets and small piazzas we arrived at Piazza di Santa Croce, a magnificent civic space dominated visually by the Church of Santa Croce, but socially by the profusion of shops, restaurants and public space.

The church is a marvel of flamboyant decorative detail on the main facade (little effort was wasted on the sides, one of which was crammed right across a street, that was more of an alley, from tiny storefronts and the back doors of residences). To our American eyes, it is strangely colorful. 

The interior of the church was more restrained than later renaissance efforts that we were to see in Rome. It was particularly interesting because of the many tombs of famous renaissance luminaries: Galileo, Machiavelli, Michelangelo, and so on. Each had a section of wall in which an elaborate sculpture was installed, paid for by patrons and the estates of the deceased, thus funding the church's activities, and enriching the overpaid clergy (vow of poverty, indeed).

Galileo's tomb, installed much later as amends for the church's mistreatment of him, features his bust plus two allegorical figures, typifying the traditional approach for all the tombs there but one. Michelangelo's alone features three allegorical figures signifying his rare mastery of the three distinct disciplines of painting, sculpture and architecture.

We had ample time to explore and lunch while on the Piazza di Santa Croce, and also met up with mom and dad, who had taken a less rigorous tour.

Here the commission the guides often earn paid off. First, Samuelé made sure we stopped in Gold Market, run by Maria, that easily captured NancyEllen's attention and a big chunk of our wallet. Second he and our parents highly recommended Boccadama. We were able to get a table in the overcrowded and popular place with no reservations because the proprietor reserves tables for Samuelé's group. Mamma Mia! What an amazing lunch! Cheap but good–tasting rustic chianti paired with the most delectable lasagna we'd ever had! We finished on the other side of the piazza with a gelato, before our tour of the inside of the church.
The tour ended at a stunning overlook encompassing views of the entire Florentine valley, and one last bronze replica of Michelangelo's David.
Each tour was exhilarating and exhausting. On the return trip, the hypnotic monologue of the tour guide would put half the bus to sleep…
